The US Treasury Yield Curve remains inverted since July 2022, with notable differences such as 0.31% between 2-year and 10-year, and 1.04% between 3-month and 10-year treasuries. This inversion, often a precursor to economic slowdowns, highlights investor concerns over short-term economic prospects. Despite this, the stock market, as reflected by the SPY ETF, has shown stability and growth. Historical data points to market expectations of future interest rate cuts, with shorter-term yields surpassing longer-term ones.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has emphasized the unsustainable trajectory of U.S. debt, advising caution with rate cuts. Correspondingly, the federal funds rate remains at 5.25-5.5%, pending further inflation reductions to the 2% target.
